query: Summarize the discussion about the spectrum of offences.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there was a spectrum of offending. At one end, it was relatively white and the other end was relatively black, but in the middle there were multiple shades of grey. In that sense, matters were clarified, because up until that point it was not entirely clear. There were a series of Court of Appeal cases that sought to clarify the law, but that was at a time, at the end of the 1990s, the start of the 2000s, when they had the European convention on human rights and they had a quickly developing body of case law. So one would hope that the law would change to reflect the way in which people behave within society.

query: What were the implications for implementing the Bill in Wales for that?
summary: Barry Hughes explained that the bill would remove a defence, which would make it likely that the police would give this more consideration for referral to the CPS than beforehand, but it didn't necessarily mean they would refer it, because it would depend on the facts of each individual case. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, his approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suits both England and Wales, and they would probably conclude that the evidential stage was met in that instance because the defence no longer existed, which took them on to considering the public interest.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the guidance when talking about the divergence
summary: Dawn Bowden AM asked about the guidance on the divergence of criminal law and whether that needed amending to reflect it. Barry Hughes answered that they would need to update the guidance, and it went back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage. On evidential and public interest stages, they might have some light-touch guidance around that.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before they made their final decision?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, they would simply want to take the present public interest factors, which were set out, in his view, very clearly in the code for Crown prosecutors, and they would provide a degree of detail around those that relates more specifically to the issues that they were discussing here. And they would need to work that up as they went along.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the issue of whether something was punishment or not was going to disappear, providing that it was clear that contact with a child had happened. The change in the law here would afford children a degree of protection that they don't presently have, but which they do have when they attain the age of 16. However, it would not alter the basic responsibility of the prosecution, which was to establish its case beyond a reasonable doubt.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the way to prevent cases even coming as far as arrest?
summary: From the perspective of the CPS, they can't direct the police. It's a matter for the police.

Suzy Davies AM asked about the practical and possibly financial implications for the workforce in this legislation. There was nothing that would impact upon their performance as the public prosecution service in that time. The chances of somebody who's currently protected by the defence and is not part of a bigger case where there's serial smacking or other difficulties in a family, for example—the chances of them getting to you in the first place were pretty low, but they were greater than they were presently. So, the numbers would be very small, which means they would be able to keep a clear track on those

query: Summarize the discussion about the factors that the CPS would be taking into consideration when applying
summary: According to Barry Hughes, when they apply the public interest test, the essence of it is about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that is proportionate to the offending. Some of them are fairly obvious, such as previous convictions. If someone's got previous convictions for doing something wrong, it's more likely they're going to be prosecuted the next time. However, there's no part of the law that says that prosecution will always follow.

According to Suzy, there is a clear spectrum of offending that you can realistically consent to and then you get to offending you can't consent to. For example, tattooing is a serious assault on one level, but you can consent to a tattoo. When it comes to much lesser assaults, the law is more unclear as to what you can

query: What did Barry Hughes think about creating a body of out-of-court disposals specific to this Bill
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the greater the level of awareness, the more likely it was that the Act, if passed, would achieve its intentions. However, he was not sure whether there should be a duty or not. It was not for him to answer that question.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the potential unintended consequences of the new law?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the number of cases referred to the CPS were likely to be very limited. When the CPS was asked to conduct a survey across all of England and Wales—this was the review in 2007—it spanned just over a two-year period, and there were 12 cases that were brought up at that stage. Now, I have to say, I don't think that's entirely reliable, but it is indicative. And, in my experience, the police were much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago, in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target.

query: Summarize the discussion about the low numbers of prosecutions.
summary: There is a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecute 5 per cent of those in any given year. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions is, for me, not a reason not to signify that certain behaviour is or is not acceptable. The criminal law provides a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. Some of the changes in this arena were driven by case law—so, that case I referred to, Regina v H, which was heard back in 2001 in the Court of Appeal, was significant in helping shape the direction of travel towards section 58.

query: What did Kay Martin think about universities in
summary: Kay Martin thought that universities in the main did not believe the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, especially the experience they had with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. However, it was mixed, and it did depend on the admissions tutors and the areas that they were going into in universities. It was valued by them and they accepted it, but when people went further afield, they were always trying to push their learners beyond.

According to Dafydd Evans, the Welsh baccalaureate has become a very rigorous, very large qualification. Actually, it's probably larger than an A-level by now. Therefore, the admissions tutors throughout a lot of universities will make different decisions, and also make the decision dependent on whether it's a facilitating subject or an enabling subject, which the Russell Group report indicates about facilitating subjects, and Welsh bac at the moment is not a facilitating

query: What did Kay Martin think about the bac?
summary: Kay Martin believed that the baccalaureate was best at producing independent, inquiry-based learners who had the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. However, it was comparable as long as it achieves the right outcome for that particular learner.

summary: Dafydd Evans thought that training was required regarding the Welsh baccalaureate, but where they are seeing it more successfully is where vocational lecturers have actually taken it on board. query: Summarize the discussion about the process of developing the curriculum.
summary: According to Kirsty, there was a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. There were 24 focus groups that were arranged for children and young people. In October, there would be a number of workshops lasting three days at a time where those practitioners would continue that process of feedback with the curriculum and assessment group and all those people involved. In terms of some of the things that people were asking us to look again at, some of that was around the language used. So, they would make a statutory provision for the 'what matters' statements within that, again, providing greater certainty and greater clarity about our expectations at a national level.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the 'What matters' statement when talking about the main purposes of the legislation?
summary: According to Kirsty, the four purposes would be set out in the legislation, followed by putting in law the areas of learning and experience. Then, below that, they were going to legislate for a number of the cross-curricular aspects—so, literacy, the numeracy and the digital competency—as well as some elements where they had already said that they would make that statutory, so, for instance, above and beyond what Graham Donaldson would have put in his original reports. The 'what matters' were the articulation of the big ideas. They were always intended to represent, as a whole, the learning that every learner should get.

query: What were the main points that were raised with
summary: According to Kirsty, there had been a significant number of people that have expressed concerns about the approaches towards RE that were set out in the White Paper. There were very mixed views on the inclusion of a range of faiths and world religions included in that area of learning. There was also a need to modernise RE; some people perceived the current curriculum as a bit old-fashioned. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views. With regard to RSE, the key messages were focused on whether children should be taught RSE at all and that this should not be in the curriculum and it shouldn't be a compulsory part of the curriculum.

query: What is the timetable for the Bill itself and for seeking Royal Assent?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, the expectation is that they will publish a final version of the curriculum in January 2020, so schools will then have the opportunity to be really engaging in it. Then, the curriculum on its own will not be enough. It is the four enabling objectives that sit around it, and they have to be cognisant of the WISERD's research, of course they do, to ensure that, as they're doing professional learning, as we're planning well-being for our children, and how they develop a culture of strong leaders in our schools—and they have some, we have many, but they need to do more to support them—it is that that will make the biggest difference.

query: What did Kirsty think about the different accountability framework to the aims and objectives of the new curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and what would have a bigger impact on children who were in danger of being left behind, were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. First of all, there would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales. Secondly, excellent teaching. In the end, no education system, whatever its curriculum, could exceed the quality of the people who stood in front of our students day in, day out.

query: What kind of lessons were being learned from the introduction of their curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first thing to realise is that their curriculum was not a copycat of the Scottish curriculum, but it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that had arisen. Assessment has been a crucial part of the process that they have been involved in. They have embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of our curriculum assessment group. They feed in throughout—not 'don't do this because Scotland has done it', but they feed some of that learning into the system.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about how they quality control the content?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that the focus had been in their work about just talking about content and, actually, the assessment arrangements were bolted on at the end of the process. So, they had pioneers who worked with clusters to test the development of that concept before they were looking for schools to go away and develop a larger amount of content. And so they were interested in looking, as I said, at some of the practices that other countries use to include pupil voice to find out what's happening.

query: Summarize the discussion about the professional development preparation.
summary: According to Kirsty, it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. The four regional consortia were working together to provide consistency for classroom teachers and teaching assistants, and then the next stage of that development would be for subject specifics. The innovation schools had led to a very specific piece of work as they did the final refinement, and their main role was working with the schools on these final refinements to the content but also to the assessment issues and accountability issues.

According to Kirsty, they would continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales will teach in England and teachers trained or who have worked in England will come across the border, as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in our schools. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. Each school is part of a network that links to it, and they gauge (1) the level of activity in it, (2) the outcomes of that work. But they've not got a monitoring system that says, "Tick every box". What they need is a mix of sector—secondary, primary—but also linguistically, to just try to make sure that this works in all the different types of schools

query: What was the feedback like with regard to the draft assessment proposals?
summary: According to Kirsty, the principles were broadly supported. They received what I would describe as positive feedback regarding the emphasis placed on ongoing assessment that was there to support children's learning and progression. The primary purpose for assessment was for that professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on, and they would absolutely expect professionals to have those conversations with parents to have that conversation about what happens next.

query: Summarize the discussion about the accountability on both sides of that thick black line.
summary: According to Kirsty, they were moving to a system of schools as learning organizations, and a greater emphasis on self-evaluation, with external verification of that by Estyn, their inspectors. The message was very clear: this was not to absolve their system of accountability. This was about better accountability, smarter accountability, not less accountability.

query: Summarize the discussion about PISA.
summary: Sian Gwenllian asked why the Welsh Government was opting out of the creative thinking tests with regard to PISA 2020. Kirsty Williams explained that the key factor for making that decision was in 2021 they would be expecting schools to be right in the middle of their preparation for the introduction of the new curriculum, so it was not the right time to do it.

According to Nick, at least one authority is looking at how they can best retain all pupils in the school setting, but it's early days yet for looking at that. It started off really well a few years ago, and they keep an eye on that, but they don't really know what the outcomes have been long term with that. But it's certainly a model worth looking at. It comes back to that team-around-the-family approach, to ensure what is needed for that learner to go back into school, what can the school provide.
